ES-4.  Five-year Accident History
There have been no accidental releases of aqua ammonia during the last five years resulting in death, injuries, evacuation, sheltering in place, or property or environmental damage.

ES-5.  The Emergency Response Program
The Facility's emergency response program has been developed in accordance with the following regulations:
*  OSHA 29 CFR 1910.38; 
*  US EPA 40 CFR Subpart E Emergency Response; and
*  Section 25503, Division 6.95 of the California Health and Safety Code, Hazardous Materials Business Plan.

The Emergency Response/Contingency Plan was updated and will be implemented in the event of a release of a regulated substance.

ES-6.  Planned Changes to Improve Safety
Safety improvement is an on-going activity at the Facility. Periodic evaluations will be performed to assess the maintenance of safe conditions. Specific changes to the aqua ammonia processes at the Facility will be implemented as needed.

ES-7.  The Worst-case Release Scenario and Alternative Release Scenario
Aqua Ammonia Worst-case and Alternative Release Scenarios. The worst-case release scenario is a release of 77,000 pounds of aqua ammonia, the volume of the largest storage tank when full, into the secondary containment berm, modeled with an increased wind speed and F Stability modeling parameters. The alternative release scenario based on the hazard review (or a more plausible potential incident) is a release from a pipe break within the secondary containment berm, modeled with an increased wind speed and D Stability modeling parameters. The toxic endpoint for the worst-case release scenario is at 0.36 miles downwind; the alternative release has a toxic endpoint that is 0.14 miles downwind from the point of release.

EXECUTIVE SUMMARY

ES-1.  Facility Accidental Release Policy
The owners, management, and employees of the Bear River Supply, Inc., Rio Oso Facility (herein referred to as BRSI or the Facility) at 218 Pleasant Grove Road, Rio Oso, California 95674 are committed to the prevention of an accidental release of aqua ammonia. If an accidental release should occur, the Facility is prepared to work with the local fire department, or other authorities to mitigate any release and minimize the impact of the release to people and the environment. A detailed Emergency Response/Contingency Plan has been developed and will be implemented in the event of an accidental release.

ES-2.  Facility Information and Stationary Substances Handled
*  The Facility is a retail agricultural facility whose primary activity is the storage and sale of fertilizers, in addition to, the sale of pre-packaged agricultural chemicals to farmers.
*  Aqua ammonia  is received by truck, stored in three, 10,000-gallon aboveground storage tanks, and distributed for direct application as crop production nutrients.
*  The maximum quantity of aqua ammonia (20.66% NH3 by weight, has a liquid density of 7.7 pounds per gallon at 60 °F and 1.59 lbs of NH3 per of solution) stored at the site is 231,000 pounds.

ES-3.  Accidental Release Prevention Program
The Facility has implemented the following prevention program elements for the management of the aqua ammonia.

Safety Information: BRSI ensures that information concerning covered processes and regulated substances are up-to-date and available for review by employees. 

Hazard Review: A hazard review of the regulated processes is conducted every five years or as needed by changes in the processes.  Results indicate that no high-risk hazards were identified through the hazard review update.

Operating Procedures: Written standard operating procedures have been developed for the covered processes and are reviewed and revised as needed.
